column1: Explore trade-off between using cleansed_text vs. base_fields integration
column30: We need to determine if it makes sense to base the context area from cleansed_text tables or base_fields. It is preferred to use cleansed_text because it goes through various cleansing operations for more valid data, however, it doesn’t have author data, which would require us to still join on base_fields to get author detail. We need to revisit to see which method is most practical to implement into the context area as well as accuracy validations.

column1: API: DELETE /brand/{id}
column30:
Add an endpoint that can delete a brand by ID, at {{DELETE /brand/{id}}}.

The GET /brand/{id} endpoint should return a 404 when attempting to get a deleted brand.

Deleting a brand should return a 204 OK response.

Attempting to delete a brand that does not exist or which has already been deleted should also return a 204 OK response.

Ensure that deleting a brand cascades to delete relationships in competitorbrandrelation, brandcommgroups, brand_topic.

--

[GROOMING] Question for product – should we delete everything related to a brand if it’s deleted? Or disallow deletion after onboarding? Related question for other tickets, should we disallow editing a brand’s name or subcategory once onboarding has taken place?

Don’t allow deleting a brand if there are any strategies associated with it. Give a 400 response with a message like “Can’t delete a brand with associated strategies.”

Don’t allow deleting a brand if there is an associated entry in the ‘contexts’ table (this likely doesn’t exist yet). Give a 400 response with a message like “Can’t delete a brand with associated context area.”

column1: Remove long string columns from the stats that Delta Lake collects
column30:
Delta Lake statistics optimization should be implemented by removing long text fields from the statistics collection. Delta automatically collects statistics on the first N columns (default 32) which enable metadata-only queries and file skipping capabilities, significantly improving query performance. However, timestamp and string types, especially long strings, reduce the effectiveness of these statistics due to precision issues and truncation that prevent exact matches. To optimize performance, the dataSkippingNumIndexedCols or dataSkippingStatsColumns property can be used to focus statistics collection on the most selective columns, excluding the long text fields that provide minimal query optimization benefit.

||Table property||Databricks Runtime supported||Description||
|{{delta.dataSkippingNumIndexedCols}}|All supported Databricks Runtime versions|Increase or decrease the number of columns on which Delta collects statistics. Depends on column order.|
|{{delta.dataSkippingStatsColumns}}|Databricks Runtime 13.3 LTS and above|Specify a list of column names for which Delta Lake collects statistics. Supersedes {{dataSkippingNumIndexedCols}}.|

[Data skipping for Delta Lake | Databricks Documentation|https://docs.databricks.com/aws/en/delta/data-skipping]

column1: API: PUT strategy details (generation)
column30:
Create an endpoint that allows AI/Ops to update a Strategy with its generated details. After a user creates a Strategy through the UI (creating a StrategySummaryDTO with status 'pending'), AI/Ops will generate recommendations and emotions for the Strategy, then call this endpoint to provide the details and update the status to 'active'.

This endpoint is a critical component that bridges the initial user-created strategy with the AI-generated content, enabling the complete Strategy experience.
column58:
* Endpoint accepts a StrategyDetailsDTO containing recommendations and emotion IDs
* Updates a Strategy's status from 'pending' to 'active'
* Creates relationships between the Strategy and its recommendations
* Creates relationships between the Strategy and its emotions
* Returns a 204 (No Content) response on success
* Returns a 404 response if the strategy does not exist
* Returns a 400 response if the request body is invalid or incomplete
* Properly enforces security through authenticated requests
column179:
* This endpoint will update the strategies table to set the status to 'active'
* It will create records in the strategy_recommendation table for each recommendation
* It will create records in the strategy_emotion table for each emotion ID
* Consider whether to create a recommendations table to store the recommendation content, or embed it directly in the strategy_recommendation table
* The insight field may correspond to recommendation_type or need a new column
* The keywords field will need to be accommodated in the database schema
* This is an internal endpoint intended to be called by AI/Ops, not directly from the UI
* Consider implementing idempotency to handle potential retries from AI/Ops
* Add appropriate logging to track the generation process


*Request:* {{PUT /strategy/{strategyId}/details}}

*Body:*

{noformat}{
  "recommendations": [
    {
      "title": "string",
      "content": "string",
      "insight": "string",
      "keywords": ["string"]
    }
  ],
  "emotionIds": ["string"]
}{noformat}

*Response*

* 204 No Content - Success
* 400 Bad Request - Invalid request body
* 404 Not Found - Strategy not found
* 403 Forbidden - Unauthorized access

column1: API: PUT audiences for brand (daily refresh)
API: PUT topics for brand (daily refresh)
column30:
The goal of this endpoint would be providing a mechanism for the ‘daily refresh’ of Topics at 6 AM.

Assumptions [GROOMING]: As new Topics become relevant to a Product Brand, we’ll want to understand there’s a relationship there. Topics may become active (or inactive) over time.

This would be our opportunity to update:

* Which Topics are related to which Brands
* What the “brand proximity” is of those topics to each brand
* Adjusting whether Topics are ‘active’

----

Create an endpoint that allows updating the relationship between a Product Brand and its relevant Topics. This endpoint will provide a mechanism for the 'daily refresh' of Topics, scheduled to run at 6 AM. It will be used by AI/Ops to update which Topics are associated with a Brand, their proximity to the Brand, and whether they are currently active.
column179:
* This endpoint will create or update records in the brand_topic table
* The brand_topic table may need to be created if it doesn't exist
* Consider whether the implementation should:
** Replace all existing topic associations for the brand (removing those not in the request)
** Or add new topic associations while keeping existing ones
* Include a brandProximity field in the brand_topic table to store the proximity value
* Consider adding an 'active' field to track whether a topic is currently active for a brand
* This is an internal endpoint intended to be called by AI/Ops, not directly from the UI
* Authentication and authorization should be properly implemented
* Add appropriate logging for this operation since it runs on a daily schedule

*Database Changes*

* Create brand_topic table if it doesn't exist with the following fields:
** brand_id (foreign key to brands table)
** topic_id (foreign key to topics table)
** brand_proximity (numeric value)
** active (boolean)
** created_at/updated_at timestamps

column1: API: Get emotions by id
column30: Create an endpoint that retrieves emotion details by their IDs. This endpoint will be used on the Strategy page to display emotion chips and information. It should return emotion data sourced from the emotions table.
column58:
* Endpoint correctly returns emotions by their IDs
* Supports fetching multiple emotions in a single request
* Returns a 404 response if any emotion ID does not exist
* Returns an empty array if no valid IDs are provided
* Returns emotion data with proper ID and name fields
* Endpoint properly enforces security through authenticated requests

*Request*

{code:json}GET /emotion?id=1&id=2&id=3{code}

*Response*

Returns an array of EmotionDTO objects:

{code:json}[
  {
    "id": "string",
    "name": "string"
  }
]{code}

*Issues to Resolve*

* Confirm whether the emotions table has a name field or if one needs to be added
* Determine if emotion data needs to be seeded as part of this ticket or as a separate task
column179:
* Data should be sourced from the emotions table
* The table currently does not appear to be populated - determine if this needs to be seeded during implementation
* No obvious name field in the current schema - confirm field mapping or add a name column if needed
* Implement proper error handling for non-existent IDs
* Consider implementing caching for this endpoint since emotion data changes infrequently
* Ensure proper filtering and security checks to prevent unauthorized data access

column1: Business Logic: Explore page section 2: Competitor Audience Insights
column30:
As a product manager, I want to see a description of a  hexbin graph and information on new audience segments based on competitor, so that I can identify new audience groups that specific are targeted by competitors.

*Hexbin Example:* [https://observablehq.com/collection/@d3/d3-hexbin|https://observablehq.com/collection/@d3/d3-hexbin|smart-link] 

*Design:* [Figma|https://www.figma.com/design/U4eAh5Xm51tYKozGaM3QGC/Explore?t=ooVxtBgGMd9UBLn3-0]

*User Story:* As a marketer, I need to understand how my audiences compare to my competitors' audiences, so I can identify opportunities to target underserved segments and optimize my marketing strategies.

*Description:* Implement the Competitor Audience Insights section of the Explore page that provides marketers with a comprehensive, data-driven view of how different audience segments (previously referred to as community groups) engage with their brand compared to competitors. This multi-faceted analysis page will visualize audience engagement metrics, demographic overlap, sentiment distribution, and engagement trends across brands in the competitive landscape.

The section will feature interactive data visualizations that allow marketers to explore audience engagement patterns at multiple levels of granularity. Users can compare audience segment performance across competitors through side-by-side metrics, revealing which audience segments show stronger affinity for their brand versus competitors. The analysis will highlight both opportunities (underserved segments where the brand could increase engagement) and threats (segments where competitors have established stronger connections).

*Technical Notes:*

* Endpoint: {{GET /brand/{brandId}/competitor}} and possibly other specialized endpoints since the API note indicates this may need multiple endpoints for the volume of data
* Response: {{BrandCompetitorDetailsDTO}} (structure TBD in backend implementation)
* Data source tables: Will need to be defined by engineering team. Please reference [Data Sources for MarTech|https://evolve24.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/bgp/pages/3091890181/Data+Sources+for+MarTech] page.
* Component dependencies:
** Audience selector component
** Competitor selector component
** Data visualization components
column58:
# UI must match design for Competitor Audience Insights
# Competitor Audience Insight Header: [Copy TBD]
## “Compare Audience Groups based on your competitors'”
# “Understanding a Hexbin graph” Sub-header
# Understanding a “hexbin graph” definition text [Copy TBD]
## “A hexbin graph is used for comparative analysis. It reveals patterns and distribution based on your competitors' target audience groups and your target audience groups.  Hover over a color to see which audience groups appeal to your competitors or your brand.”
## Helpful hint:  Remember each audience group tells a story of how different people are grouped based on habits, interests, or choices.  This leads to better decision making based on real behavior!

column1: Business Logic: Explore page section 2: Competitor Audience Hexbin
column30:
As a marketer, I want to view audience communication density visualizations for my brand and each competitor individually, so I can understand the intensity and distribution of brand-specific conversations.

*Description:* Develop a visual representation of audience communication density using hexbin charts for the user’s brand and its two competitors. Each chart provides insight into how actively and densely each brand is discussed across audience segments, enabling marketing teams to evaluate brand visibility and engagement hotspots.

*Design:* [Figma Design|https://www.figma.com/design/U4eAh5Xm51tYKozGaM3QGC/Explore?node-id=4002-39643&t=bswKrfjUEdwXVMBE-1]

*Data:* [Data Sources For MarTech|https://evolve24.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/bgp/pages/3091890181/Data+Sources+for+MarTech]

*Technical Details:*

* Endpoint: {{GET /brand/{brandId}/competitor}} and possibly other specialized endpoints since the API note indicates this may need multiple endpoints for the volume of data
* Response: {{BrandCompetitorDetailsDTO}} (structure TBD in backend implementation)
* Data source tables: Will need to be defined by engineering team
* Component dependencies:
** Audience card component
** Score visualization component
** Reach indicator component
** Tab navigation component for competitor selection

h3. Data Stores

The dashboard will rely on the following database tables:

# *Core Entity Tables*
#* {{brands}} - Brand information
#* {{commgroups}} - Audience/community group data
#* {{topics}} - Topic information
#* {{emotions}} - Emotion categories
# *Relationship Tables*
#* {{brand_commgroup}} - Relates brands to audience groups
#* {{brand_topic}} - Links brands to relevant topics
#* {{topic_commgroup}} - Relates topics to audience groups
#* {{strategy_emotion}} - Connects strategies with emotions
# *Metrics Tables* (to be created)
#* {{brand_resonance_trends}} - Time series data for resonance scores
#* {{audience_density_maps}} - Embedding data for hexbin visualization
#* {{topic_resonance_scores}} - Topic relevance and engagement metrics
column58:
* Create a tabbed interface with three tabs:
** Competitor A
** Competitor B
** User’s Brand
* For each tab:
** Render an independent hexbin visualization
** Use the same color gradient from purple (low) to yellow (high) to indicate communication volume
** Do *not* vary colors by brand — clarify that color = density
** Provide an independent title (e.g., “Competitor A Volume of Communications”)
** Add supporting text: “The Hexbin graph illustrates ‘density’ of communication about the selected product brand”
* Bottom label: “[Brand] Audiences by Volume of Communications”
Include a legend from 1 to 95 on the side
** Enable hover tooltips showing exact density values and audience label if available (e.g., “Barefoot Runners”)
** Charts should remain visually consistent in scale to allow fair comparison
** Ensure proper responsive behavior for desktop and tablet
** Match styling, padding, and tab layout in the provided [design mockup|https://www.figma.com/design/U4eAh5Xm51tYKozGaM3QGC/Explore?node-id=4002-32796&t=usWi7mwpTbzSVn5X-1]

column1: UI: Explore page -Topics section
column30:
*User Story:* As a marketer, I need to see how different topics perform across my brand and competitors, so I can identify which topics to emphasize in my content and messaging strategy.

*Description:* Implement the Topics section of the Explore page matching the heat map visualization shown in the mockup. This section displays a detailed breakdown of topic performance scores for competitors across multiple categories, presented in a color-coded tabular format. This visualization helps marketers understand the specific topics that resonate with audiences and how topic engagement differs across brands.

*Design:* [Explore Product Brand|https://www.figma.com/design/U4eAh5Xm51tYKozGaM3QGC/Explore?node-id=4002-32796&t=FGoPJDxvnX4g8TeO-1]

*Data Sources:* [Data Sources for MarTech|https://evolve24.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/bgp/pages/3091890181/Data+Sources+for+MarTech]
column58:
UI must match the design for the Explore page. [Explore Page|https://www.figma.com/design/U4eAh5Xm51tYKozGaM3QGC/Explore?node-id=4002-40689&t=Cnqx1DO6aRqqQo8x-1]

* Create the heat map table visualization exactly as shown in the mockup
* Implement the color gradient from red/orange (higher scores) to purple (lower scores)
* Display topic categories with their corresponding scores (scale of 0-1)
* Include the topic categories shown in the mockup:
** Marathon Session (0.9)
** Memorial Day Run (0.84)
** Friends and Family Run (0.74)
** Running Conscious Families (0.72)
** Football (0.69)
** Outdoor Sports (0.61)
** Movement (0.58)
** Soccer (0.47)

column1: UI: Explore Page - Audience section
column30:
*User Story:* As a user, I want to explore competitor positioning by audience on the explore main page, so that I can understand how my product brand compares to competitors.



*Description:* This feature will enable users to analyze competitor positioning through audience data visualization and insights. The implementation should follow the design specifications from the [Explore Page Product Brand Figma|https://www.figma.com/design/U4eAh5Xm51tYKozGaM3QGC/Explore?node-id=4002-32796&t=FGoPJDxvnX4g8TeO-1].
column58:
h3. Layout Structure

* The Audience section must contain two main columns:
** Competitor Audience visualization (left)
** Insights panel (right)

h3. Competitor Audience Visualization

* *Header Section*
** Primary header: "Audience Comparison"
** Subheader: "Visualize audience overlap between your brand and competitors"
* *Hexbin Plot Requirements*
** Support visualization of three distinct companies:
*** User's product brand
*** Two competitor product brands
** Color-code each company distinctly in the visualization
** Implement toggle controls to show/hide each company independently
** Enable hover interactions to display audience group details
** Include a color legend clearly identifying which color represents which company

h3. Insights Panel

* *Header Section*
** Primary header: "Audience Insights"
** Subheader: "Key takeaways from audience comparison"
* *Content*
** Display relevant insights based on the visualization data
** Include a helpful hint section with guidance on how to interpret the data
** Present actionable recommendations based on audience overlap analysis

h2. Design References

* Follow UI specifications from [Product Brand – Figma|https://www.figma.com/design/U4eAh5Xm51tYKozGaM3QGC/Explore?node-id=4002-32796&t=FGoPJDxvnX4g8TeO-1]
* Match the look and feel of the existing Explore page sections

h2. Technical Notes

* Ensure the visualization is responsive and performance-optimized
* Implement proper data loading states and error handling
* The feature should integrate with existing audience data APIs ([Data Sources for MarTech|https://evolve24.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/bgp/pages/3091890181/Data+Sources+for+MarTech])

column1: UI Business Logic: Audience Details Modal
column30:
As a product manager, I want the audience groups to be mapped to the backend API so that when a user clicks on the details button in an Audience Group card (like "Fun Run with Dogs"), the modal will display accurate data including the group name, reach percentage, overview, and a detailed breakdown of related topics with their respective reach values.

As a marketer, I want to view detailed information about audience groups so I can understand their composition, reach, and relevance to my brand before adding them to my marketing strategy.

This ticket involves implementing the Audience Group Modal that appears when a user clicks the "See details" button on an audience group card, displaying comprehensive information about the group including its name, reach, overview, and related topic distribution.

----

*Figma:* [https://www.figma.com/design/ZqWVRrOdUxZ5nzKUlnUowZ/Homepage?node-id=2178-11&p=f&t=G7pKly6D2S3nfPEO-0|https://www.figma.com/design/ZqWVRrOdUxZ5nzKUlnUowZ/Homepage?node-id=2178-11&p=f&t=G7pKly6D2S3nfPEO-0|smart-link] 

!Screenshot 2025-05-05 at 12.14.00 PM.png|width=91.66666666666666%,alt="Screenshot 2025-05-05 at 12.14.00 PM.png"!

*Dependencies*

* This ticket depends on [CLP-880|https://evolve24.atlassian.net/browse/CLP-880] (Context Area Topic Modal) shares UI patterns and components
* Requires the audience group API endpoint to be available with complete data
* "Add to strategy" button functionality may depend on the Strategy Builder component (shown in mockup)

h2. Additional Notes

* The modal design follows the pattern established in the design system - ensure consistency with other modals
* The "Add to strategy" functionality may need to be implemented in a separate ticket if it requires complex integration with the Strategy Builder
* Consider implementing skeleton loading states for better UX while data is loading
* Ensure the audience overview text area can handle variable length content
* Table should have proper scrolling behavior if the number of segments exceeds the visible area
* Verify with product team if the color gradient is based on a specific metric or just for visual differentiation
column58:
* The Audience Group Modal appears when a user clicks "See details" on an audience group card
* The modal displays the audience group name (e.g., "Fun Run with Dogs") as the header
* The modal shows the audience group's reach percentage (e.g., "22.7% reach") prominently
* The "Audience overview" section displays descriptive text about the group from the API
* The modal shows a color-coded table of related topics with three columns:
** Name
** % of audience
** Reach %
* The table uses a consistent color gradient from orange/red to purple
* An "Add to strategy" button appears in the top right of the modal
* Clicking "Add to strategy" adds the audience group to the Strategy Builder and updates the reach calculation
* The modal can be closed using the X button in the top right
* Loading states appear while data is being fetched
* Error states display appropriate messages if the data cannot be retrieved

This ticket involves connecting the frontend UI components for the Context Area Topic Modal with the appropriate backend API endpoints, ensuring proper data rendering, and implementing the interactive elements shown in the mockups.

column1: Update TopNav with updated tabs for subpages
column30:
The main remaining purpose of this story is to ensure that the Organization/User tabs are appropriately suppressed for non-SuperAdmin users.

Legacy ticket content is below.

----

*User Stories:*

* As user, I want to see a clear, labeled navigation bar so that I can explore the platform easily without confusion. ☑️
* As user, I want quick access to major modules (Home, Strategies, Explore) so that I can complete tasks faster. ☑️
* -As a product manager, I want the Strategies navigation tab to be disabled when no strategies have been created, so that customers don’t have access unless a strategy has been created.-

*Scope:* 

* Update the global navigation per design file: Home, Strategies, Explore, Gear icon, company name dropdown and ability to logout. 
** here, we just need to make sure that the Organization and User tabs are hidden for non-SuperAdmin users [GROOMING: confirm]
* Have the tab dynamically highlight the user’s active page in the global nav ☑️
* Ensure the global nav is responsive ☑️

** -Strategies tab should display in a disabled state in global nav-
** -Keep text readable but muted-
** -Clicking should do nothing-

column1: API: Reach Calculation and Audience Deduplication
column30:
As a marketer, I want accurate reach numbers that account for audience overlap between communities and topics, so I can make informed decisions about my marketing strategy and budget allocation.

*Context*: We need to implement a high-performance service that calculates deduplicated audience reach across multiple communities, topics, and demographic segments. This service is a core component of the Clarvos platform that will enable marketers to accurately measure potential campaign impact.

Reach is the sum of all authors.

This is a critical backend service for the Strategy Builder panel that calculates the total potential reach across selected communities and topics. The service needs to account for audience overlap to prevent overestimating reach. Reach equates to one customer that the marketer is targeting. 

*User Story*: As a marketing professional, I want to see a real-time total reach calculation as I add or remove communities and topics to my strategy, so I can understand the impact of my selections and optimize for maximum audience coverage.

*Business Value*:

* Provides accurate, deduplicated reach numbers for better budget planning
* Differentiates from competitors by accounting for audience overlap
* Enables marketers to make data-driven decisions about which communities to target
* Increases trust in the platform by providing transparent, accurate metrics

*Internal Product Context*: This service powers the Strategy Builder panel on the homepage, which displays the total estimated reach and a progress bar showing how much of the maximum possible reach has been selected. The calculation needs to update in real-time as users add or remove communities and topics.

Confluence: [https://evolve24.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/bgp/pages/2806710280/Entity+Resolution+that+identifies+and+deduplicates+similar+records.|https://evolve24.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/bgp/pages/2806710280/Entity+Resolution+that+identifies+and+deduplicates+similar+records.|smart-link]
column58:
* Service correctly calculates deduplicated reach across selected audience segments
* Handles both Level 1 clusters (up to 10.5M individuals) and Level 2 clusters (as small as 3,000 individuals)
* Calculations complete within 500ms for 95% of requests (up to 10 selected segments)
* Calculations complete within 2000ms for complex requests (11-30 selected segments)
* API supports both synchronous requests for small calculations and asynchronous processing for larger computations
* Results include confidence intervals based on sampling methodology
* Performance metrics are logged for monitoring and optimization
* Implements caching strategy for frequently requested segment combinations
* Includes fallback mechanism for degraded performance scenarios
* Provides Swagger/OpenAPI documentation for all endpoints

column1: API: Topics Data Integration for Homepage Carousel
column30:
This ticket involves creating the API endpoints needed to power the topics carousel on the homepage, leveraging the BERTopic standard Wikipedia model for topic classification which Data Science has completed and can be found in Databricks:{{dev_data_warehouse.michalm.bertopic_standard_wikipedia_model}}

As a backend developer, I need to integrate the Topics API to provide data for the homepage carousel so marketers can see the topics that present the greatest opportunity for their brand by community.



*User Story 1:*

As a marketer, I want each topic tag to show the estimated total reach so I can assess its potential.

h3. Topics Model Details

* Databricks Model: {{dev_data_warehouse.michalm.bertopic_standard_wikipedia_model}}
* The Topics model classifies text by identifying semantically relevant topics from a set of 2,377 topic embeddings
* Each topic has a unique ID, representative keywords, and a human-readable label
* Matching logic uses cosine similarity with a threshold of 0.4
* Maximum of 20 topics per input will be returned by the model
* Results are provided as a tuple of three lists: topic IDs, similarity scores, and topic label
* {noformat}(
  [topic_id_1, topic_id_2, ...],         # Topic IDs
  [score_1, score_2, ...],               # Similarity scores (float)
  [label_1, label_2, ...]                # Corresponding topic labels
){noformat}

h2. Edge Cases

* Handle scenarios where topics data is not available
* Implement proper error handling for model API failures
* Handle rate limiting and performance concerns
* Consider pagination for initial load vs. "load more" functionality
* Handle cases where fewer than 10 topics meet the similarity threshold
* Ensure consistent ordering when topics have identical reach values

h2. Other Details

* Topics are static for P0 (refresh daily) per working session
* No trending indicators (up/down) for P0
* Connect to Topics API endpoint for data

h3. Future Enhancements (Post-July 1)

* Models with non-null _Representative_Doc_ values for each context area will be added.
* Structure of the document and classification logic will remain the same.
column58:
* Create endpoint to fetch top topics by reach for the carousel
* Order topics by reach (highest to lowest, displayed left to right)
* Return at most 10 topics for the initial implementation (to match mock data)
* Include topic name, reach number, and appropriate icons in response
* Return topics with similarity scores ≥ 0.4 (per model documentation)
* Ensure proper error handling and logging
* Return appropriate data structures that match frontend requirements in CLP-740
* Implement response caching where appropriate for performance

column1: Identify New Authors
column30: Within a context area, we may get new authors that are not mapped to a group or don’t have a proper author identified. We need to create a process that provides a map group to these authors, or, do we need to do that? We still need to identify how this challenge will be resolved.

column1: API: Communities: Implement business logic for endpoint loading communities data for company
column30:
As a backend developer, I need to implement the business logic for retrieving and processing community data specific to a company, so that the frontend can display relevant community cards on the homepage.

As a marketer, I want to see community groups that are relevant to my company, so I can identify untapped markets where my competitors are strong but my brand has limited presence.

*Context*: This ticket is part of the homepage implementation, specifically powering the community cards grid section. The communities displayed represent growth opportunities for brands, showing areas where competitors have penetrated markets that the customer hasn't fully leveraged yet. This is a core value proposition of the Clarvos platform, helping marketers identify untapped markets based on data science.

*User Story*: As a marketing professional using Clarvos, I want to see a curated set of community groups relevant to my company, so I can quickly identify and add the most promising audience segments to my strategy.

*Business Value*:

* Enables marketers to discover untapped audience segments
* Provides data-driven recommendations for market expansion
* Helps identify competitive gaps and opportunities
* Increases the value of the platform by leveraging proprietary community data

*Internal Product Context*: This endpoint supports the community cards grid on the homepage, which displays up to 5 communities initially with the ability to expand to show up to 10 total. Each community card shows the name, reach number, descriptive text, and an "Add" button. Communities are presented in order of reach (highest to lowest) and grouped by category.

*Edge Cases*:

* Handle scenarios where a company has fewer than 5 relevant communities
* Implement fallback strategy for new companies with limited data
* Handle cases where community reach data might be null or zero
* Manage potential race conditions in concurrent requests
* Implement timeout handling for long-running queries
* Add graceful degradation if related services are unavailable

*Dependencies*:

* Requires Community entity model
* Needs CompanyRepository for company data access
* Requires proper database schema with community-company relationships
* May need integration with Data Science API for relevance calculations
column58:
* When I load the homepage, I should see up to 5 relevant community cards for my company
* Each community card should display the name, reach number, and descriptive text
* Communities should be ordered by reach (highest to lowest)
* Communities should be grouped by category (Fun Run with Dogs, Suburban 5K, etc.)
* If I click "More Communities," I should see up to 5 additional communities
* Communities shown should represent areas where my competitors are strong but my brand has limited presence
* The data should be specific to my company's market and competitors

column1: API: Topics: Implement business logic for loading Topics for company
column30:
*Description*: As a marketer, I want to see trending topics relevant to my brand, so I can discover new contextual areas for positioning and incorporate them into my marketing strategy.

*Context*: This ticket is part of the homepage implementation, specifically powering the Topics Carousel at the top of the page. The topics displayed represent context areas where the brand can improve its positioning. This feature leverages the BERTopic model to identify semantically relevant topics from a predefined set of topic embeddings.

*User Story*: As a marketing professional using Clarvos, I want to see a curated set of trending topics relevant to my company, so I can quickly identify and add the most promising contextual areas to my strategy.

*Business Value*:

* Enables marketers to discover new contextual areas for brand positioning
* Highlights opportunities in trending conversation spaces
* Provides data-driven topic recommendations based on market dynamics
* Increases platform value by leveraging proprietary topic classification models

*Internal Product Context*: This endpoint supports the Topics Carousel at the top of the homepage, which displays topics ordered by reach. Each topic card shows the name, reach number, and includes "See details" and "Add" buttons. The data comes from the BERTopic model which classifies text by identifying semantically relevant topics from a set of 2,377 topic embeddings.
column58:
* When I load the homepage, I should see relevant topics for my company displayed in the carousel
* Topics should be ordered by reach (highest to lowest)
* Each topic should include a name and reach number
* Topics shown should be relevant to my company's market and brand positioning
* The API should return at most 10 topics for the initial implementation
* Topics should be refreshed daily as per the working session decision

column1: Resonance Data available to MarTech app
column30: We need a mechanism for Emotion data to be available to MarTech database (whether via push, pull, or DS API). When aligning with SWE team, we have identified to use a data push to GCP GCS. Initial and daily data loads will be pushed there, but we need to identify the proper shared file type and data structure. Preference from backend team is to use json, but not sure if that is the proper form. Spark works native .parquet files, so we need to determine which method works best for spark and the backend data requirements.
column58: We are able to successfully push data to GCS, data is structured in a format that successfully allows append/insert operations, and we have alignment with SWE on data structure, folder directory, and file types. Lastly, data can be consumed successfully by backend team.
column179: Initial idea is to segment data structure by: org_id → backend data schema model, or whatever makes most sense for scalability and proper organization.

column1: UI: Integrate with Resonance API for loading company/product resonance

There is some confusion between what we call things in our database/API/code, and what the product team calls it. If possible, we should identify some of these areas and better align them to avoid confusion. For example, what product calls a “company” or “corporate brand” we refer to as an org. What product calls a “business unit brand” we refer to as a “company”. See attached spreadsheet.



Where it’s not disruptive, it may be nice to better align these to avoid confusion.

column1: Create LLM Regex Helper PoC
column30: We need a way to streamline and assist users with the regex creation process. We plan to utilize LLM’s to help us identify multiple named entity recognition (NER) variations. This could either be utilized to help the user craft the regex manually, or integrate directly into the UI PoC. This LLM is not meant to create the regex, but rather help identify the NER variations, something similar that was done by Salience in the past.
column58: Identify a potential solution that can aid with regex creation and management.
column179: Create a trial PoC with basic LLM and prompt generation. Craft a structured output that provides 5 - 10 entity variations that can be added to regex. Add this component to the UI in a PoC state.
column199: 15/May/25 12:08 PM;712020:8d50f2c1-55dd-4dff-a75a-716160061869;This ticket was raised that it may have jumped from sprint to sprint, but I do not recall why or if it even did. I do not believe it slipped passed sprints.

column1: Design Testing Framework
column30:
Create a testing framework that is best applied to a data engineering pipeline for context areas. Key areas that will need to be populated include:

* Unit tests
* Schema checks
* Data Type checks
* Null distributions across daily runs
* Day-over-day regression testing and variance checks
column58: Create a robust testing framework that will instill trust into the pipeline.

column1: Modularize & Package PoC Notebook Code
column30: Once the PoC notebook and workflows prove successful, the code will need to be modularized and structured in a way that can be deployed properly. We will also evaluate whether this process best fits in a notebook format or in a python module script format, in regards to coding best practices. We need to assess simplicity, ease of use, interpretability, and other robustness.
column58: Structure the code in a way that makes the most sense of understanding and deploying.
